stem: The nurse is reviewing the EHR of a client who had a right tibial fracture and has been prescribed partial weight-bearing crutch walking. Based on the EHR data, which of the following actions are MOST appropriate? For each action, click to specify whether it is appropriate or inappropriate. Then, of the options in the second column, indicate the MOST likely potential condition of the client. Finally, identify which client parameters are MOST important to monitor.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 07:00 S: Client reports increased pain (6/10) in right lower leg with ambulation. States, "I'm not sure I'm doing this crutch thing right." O: Client is post-op day 3 from ORIF right tibial fracture. Currently prescribed partial weight-bearing on right leg. Ambulation observed in hallway using 4-point gait. Demonstrates inconsistent weight-bearing on right leg, favoring left leg. Upper body strength appears adequate. A: Ineffective crutch walking technique secondary to pain and inadequate understanding of weight-bearing restrictions. Risk for falls. P: Will reinforce proper crutch walking technique with emphasis on weight-bearing restrictions and pain management. Consult physical therapy for further evaluation and gait training. Educate on importance of adhering to prescribed weight-bearing status. Encourage use of pain medication prior to ambulation. Assess pain level and ambulation technique with each shift. 07:15 Pain medication administered. 07:45 Client reports pain reduced to 3/10. Will reassess after ambulation training.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Alert and oriented x3, appears anxious. Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. Musculoskeletal: Right lower leg with surgical dressing, moderate edema. Limited range of motion in right ankle. Neuro: Sensation intact bilaterally.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Partial weight-bearing on right lower extremity.
  • Ambulate with crutches 3 times daily.
  • Pain medication as needed.
  • Consult physical therapy.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
• Oxycodone 5mg PO q4h PRN pain.
  • Acetaminophen 650mg PO q6h PRN pain.

actions.text: Demonstrate proper crutch walking technique and weight-bearing restrictions.
Encourage the client to bear as much weight as possible on the affected leg to promote healing.
Instruct the client to avoid using pain medication to prevent dependence.
Consult with physical therapy for further gait training and evaluation.

parameters.text: Wound appearance at the surgical site.

rationale.correct: The client is demonstrating ineffective crutch walking technique and is at an increased risk of falls. It is important to demonstrate proper technique and consult with physical therapy for further evaluation. Monitoring pain and adherence to weight-bearing restrictions will help prevent falls and promote healing.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect actions and parameters can lead to increased pain, delayed healing, and increased risk of falls.

answerBreakdown.explanation: Correct: Demonstrating proper crutch walking technique and weight-bearing restrictions is essential to prevent falls and promote healing. The client's current technique is ineffective, as noted in the nurse's notes.
Incorrect: The client is prescribed partial weight-bearing. Encouraging full weight-bearing can disrupt the healing process and cause further injury.
Incorrect: Pain management is important for promoting comfort and adherence to the rehabilitation plan. Avoiding pain medication can increase pain and hinder ambulation.
Correct: Consulting with physical therapy is appropriate for further gait training and evaluation. Physical therapists are experts in mobility and rehabilitation.
Correct: The client's inconsistent weight-bearing and reports of pain during ambulation indicate an increased risk of falls.
Incorrect: While proper weight-bearing is important for overall healing, the primary immediate concern is the client's fall risk.
Incorrect: While immobility can increase the risk of DVT, the immediate concern based on the data is fall risk due to improper crutch walking.
Incorrect: There is no indication in the provided data that the client is experiencing peripheral neuropathy.
Correct: Pain level during ambulation is an important parameter to monitor as it affects the client's ability to ambulate safely and adhere to weight-bearing restrictions.
Incorrect: While wound appearance is important, it is not the MOST important parameter to monitor in this scenario. The priority is client safety during ambulation.
Correct: The client's adherence to weight-bearing restrictions is critical to promote healing and prevent further injury. Inconsistent weight-bearing is a key issue.

Incorrect: While assessing pulses is important for circulation, it is not the MOST important parameter to monitor in this scenario. The priority is client safety during ambulation and adherence to weight-bearing restrictions.

clinicalPearls: Proper crutch walking technique is essential for patients with lower extremity injuries or surgeries. Ensure the client understands weight-bearing restrictions and can demonstrate the correct gait.
Pain management is crucial for promoting comfort and adherence to the rehabilitation plan. Encourage the client to use pain medication as prescribed.
Physical therapy plays a vital role in gait training and evaluation. Consult with physical therapy for further assistance and support.

questionTrap.trap: The question trap is to focus solely on the surgical wound or pain management without considering the immediate risk of falls. Some options may seem reasonable but do not address the most pressing safety concern.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize safety and identify the most immediate risk to the client. In this case, the client's ineffective crutch walking technique and pain during ambulation indicate an increased risk of falls.

mnemonic.title: SAFE Crutch Walking
mnemonic.expansion: S - Show proper technique, A - Assess pain, F - Follow weight-bearing orders, E - Evaluate with PT
